The 2013 Tightening Of The NY False Claims Act

Law360, New York (January 8, 2014, 6:08 PM ET) -- ​The New York False Claims Act has been called the “False Claims Act on steroids.” And in many respects, the state statute lives up to its characterization — the statute was amended in 2010 to include liability for tax fraud specifically exempted under the federal statute, and also has a longer statute of limitations, a lower pleading standard for relators, and a narrower public disclosure bar.

article_metadata.description: ​The New York False Claims Act has been called the "FCA on steroids," and in many respects, it lives up to this characterization. In 2013 alone, the state statute was again amended and new regulations were proposed to bring the state law further into line with — or to surpass — the federal FCA statute with respect to liabilities, whistleblower protections and compensation, and damages, say Lori Pines and Nadya Salcedo of Weil Gotshal & Manges LLP.
